author: poojaranjan
content:
EIPIP Meeting 51 
Date and Time - Wednesday, Mar 09, 2022, at 15:00 UTC
Agenda: https://github.com/ethereum-cat-herders/EIPIP/issues/112

author: poojaranjan
content: Reminder: EIPIP meeting starting in 1 hr.

author: poojaranjan
content:
Join Zoom Meeting
https://us02web.zoom.us/j/82357016731?pwd=V0hLUWIvU2V2UTdUd216WHdGNFBKUT09

author: poojaranjan
content: EIPIP meeting starting shortly!

author: gcolvin
content: Conflict, sorry.

author: gcolvin
content: Auction?  We editors can just start assigning those unused numbers whenever we want.

author: yperbasis
content: Can we please move EIP-3651 to Review since it's considered for inclusion in Shanghai?

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't want to introduce a vector for favoritism by having us choose who gets the best numbers and who gets the crappy numbers.

author: sky.cactus
content: Either the author needs to submit a PR to move it out of Stagnant, or someone needs to create a fork of it that is not stagnant.

author: gcolvin
content: Start with the smallest ones and work up.  No favorites.  They're just numbers after all.  Or, most likely, they just sit there, causing no real problems.

author: sky.cactus
content:
The issue being solved by an auction is:
1. For people who desire a specific number, give them a way to have it.
2. Fundraising for useful things.
We can solve just (1) and not (2) by burning the bids, or we can solve (1) and a bit of (2) by allocating the assets somewhere useful.

author: sky.cactus
content: It isn't that we have a bunch of unused numbers that we want to use, it is that people want to use nice looking numbers for their project.

author: gcolvin
content: If someone volunteers to run the auction I'm OK with it.  But I'm not sure why people care so much.  An objection might be that using old, small numbers gives the impression that proposals are older than they are.

author: sky.cactus
content: I also don't know why people care so much, but they do.  ü§∑

author: gcolvin
content: I notice that EIP-666 is available.  I should snag that for some nefarious purpose üòâ

author: poojaranjan
content: No worries, recording is available now.

author: poojaranjan
content:
One thing that was on agenda today was the **new time for EIPIP meeting**.
With DST starting in the USA from March 13, I would like to take the opportunity to revisit the time to schedule meeting. Here is a google form https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSchmERP_dueiskdi-SlJCa57s7p7Ku5u_wTOJtlqTefpENglg/viewform to collect input from EIP editors and interested participants to join the meeting. Based on the responses received we can schedule the next meeting.

author: poojaranjan
content: I'd encourage all EIP editors to respond to the survey and help us schedule the meeting so we can have most of the EIP editors join the meeting. Thank you to those who already filled up the form.

author: samwilsn
content: Stuff like this is why I think we need a better process for managing ownership.

author: samwilsn
content: If it gets into shanghai and merged, it'll become "final", regardless of the EIP's status.

author: sky.cactus
content: The owner could add someone else as an additional author in this case.

author: sky.cactus
content: It *shouldn't* go into Shanghai, at least not as that number and without an active author.

author: sky.cactus
content: What I fear with assigning new authors is taking on the responsibility and inevitably dealing with disputes around such decision making.

author: sky.cactus
content: What if the author is just on vacation and when they get back their thing has been reassigned?

author: samwilsn
content: That just pushes the decision making onto the core devs, who likely don't care if it's EIP-6541 or EIP-7866 as long as the text is the same.

author: sky.cactus
content: I wonder if a lot of our problems step from EIP numbers being too human readable and too prominent...

author: sky.cactus
content: I bet if we gave out GUIDS instead, people would stop caring so much about stuff like what number they got, or whether forking results in a new number...

author: samwilsn
content: That is certainly a concern. Only EIPs in a certain state (say stagnant) would be claimable.

author: sky.cactus
content: This EIP was stagnant when the author brought it to the ACD call last week.

author: samwilsn
content: Having short, human readable (and importantly speakable) identifiers is probably the biggest benefit of the EIPs repository over random blog posts?

author: sky.cactus
content: I got the impression the author cares about pushing this through, but they just haven't updated.

author: sky.cactus
content: Even if we had a policy of reassigning, I wouldn't apply it here.

author: sky.cactus
content: The author actively championed it (I believe) less than a week ago in a voice call.  This suggests to be it is very much not abandoned.

author: samwilsn
content: That makes sense

author: sky.cactus
content: That being said, we should be more strict about EIPs not being brought up for CFI until they are in review cc <@552133098075193354>

author: sky.cactus
content: That would avoid this specific class of problems I think, and I believe it is already a "rule" somewhere, just one that isn't followed well.

author: samwilsn
content: What is the difference between Draft and Review anyway?

author: samwilsn
content: Like practically.

author: sky.cactus
content: Draft means you are still actively iterating on it.  Review means you think you are done, but it still may receive iteration due to external feedback,

author: gcolvin
content: https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/4887

author: sky.cactus
content: Essentially, don't bother looking at draft EIPs, the author hasn't even finished writing them.

author: samwilsn
content: Should've waited for April! üòÆ

author: sky.cactus
content: (except for editors, we look at them)

author: samwilsn
content: So stagnant and review are more similar than draft and review üòâ

author: samwilsn
content: But yeah, that makes sense.

author: gcolvin
content: Bikeshedding.  We used to be like IETF.  They have only two statuses: Draft and Standard.

author: timbeiko
content: This is hard but I have to disagree; we can nudge people to move things to review, yes, but getting to consensus takes time and I‚Äôll push back against things that make it longer. Also, there is a trade off between waiting to officially include something because it‚Äôs not in Review and then having an incomplete spec for Shanghai‚Ä¶

author: timbeiko
content: Maybe I should just get force push rights on the EIP repo üëπ

author: sky.cactus
content: If an EIP isn't in review *in principal* (meaning, the author isn't done writing it) then I don't think we should consider it for inclusion in mainnet (regardless of the EIP status).  We can talk about it, bet CFI IMO should require a complete solution, not just a rough Idea you are iterating on.

author: timbeiko
content: Ah yes that I agree

author: timbeiko
content: And I think it‚Äôs generally the case?

author: timbeiko
content: The biggest exceptions right now is we seem to be in a limbo state for beacon chain withdrawals but it‚Äôs moving along nicely

author: sky.cactus
content: If an EIP is in review in principal, just not in the document, then it is literally a 30 second task to submit the PR to move it to review and if no one wants to do that then no one actually cares about the EIP and it will cause problems down the road and we shouldn't include it.

author: timbeiko
content: Right, but you need the author to approve it, correct?

author: sky.cactus
content: Usually the author is the one championing it, and they would be the one to submit the PR.

author: timbeiko
content: If you only need EIP editors, I‚Äôm willing to personally commit to updating EIPs that don‚Äôt get updated and pinging you and lightclient for merge

author: sky.cactus
content: You need the author.

author: sky.cactus
content: Authors who don't want to deal with "process" can just do a single PR to add you as an author then you can do exactly this.

author: timbeiko
content: Actually was about to suggest that

author: timbeiko
content: Peter did it for some networking EIPs

author: sky.cactus
content: Maybe we should make that more clear to authors who abhor "bureaucracy".  Just add Tim and you can stop dealing with it.

author: sky.cactus
content: In this specific case, I think the author just took a weekend is all.

author: timbeiko
content: You can use that too, <@!301186049323958275> üòÑ: tell (Core) EIP champions they can ping me if the bureaucracy is too much of an overhead

author: sky.cactus
content: Note to self: throw Tim under the bus more often.

author: timbeiko
content: Yes, and I now have job security for life üòé

author: sky.cactus
content: Ugh, I wish I could have less of that...

author: gcolvin
content: "Lasciate ogne speranza, voi ch'intrate."
